John David Podesta Jr.
(born January 8, 1949)
who served as Senior Advisor to the President for International Climate Policy from 2024 to 2025
having previously served as the Senior Advisor to the President for Clean Energy Innovation and Implementation from 2022 to 2025
White House chief of staff to President Bill Clinton from 1998 to 2001
counselor to President Barack Obama from 2014 to 2015
as White House staff secretary from 1993 to 1995
White House deputy chief of staff for operations from 1997 to 1998
On January 31, 2024, it was announced that Podesta would succeed John Kerry as top U.S. climate diplomat
In 1967, Podesta graduated from Lane Tech High School in Chicago
In 1971, he graduated from Knox College in Galesburg, Illinois
He received his J.D. from Georgetown University Law Center in 1976
Department of Justice's Honors Program in the Land and Natural Resources Division (1976–77)
Special Assistant to the Director of ACTION, the Federal volunteer agency (1978–79)
His political career began in 1972, when he worked for George McGovern's unsuccessful presidential campaign.
Counselor to Democratic Leader Senator Thomas Daschle (1995–96)
Chief Counsel for the Senate Agriculture Committee (1987–88)
Counsel on the Majority Staff of the Senate Judiciary Committee (1979–81)
In 1988, he and his brother Tony co-founded Podesta Associates, Inc.
Podesta in 1993 served as both an assistant to the president and as deputy chief of staff.

Earlier, from January 1993 to 1995, he was assistant to the president, staff secretary and a senior policy adviser on government information, privacy, telecommunications security and regulatory policy.
In 1998, he became President Clinton's chief of staff in the second Clinton administration
and served in the position until the end of Clinton's time in office in January 2001.
In 2003, Podesta founded the Center for American Progress, a liberal think tank in Washington, D.C., and served as its president and CEO until he stepped down in 2011.
In 2003, Podesta founded the Center for American Progress, a liberal think tank in Washington, D.C., and served as its president and CEO until he stepped down in 2011.
of August 2020, although not as chairman.
From 2002 to 2014, Podesta served as a member of the Constitution Project's bipartisan Liberty and Security Committee.
In 2008, he authored The Power of Progress: How America's Progressives Can (Once Again) Save Our Economy, Our Climate, and Our Country.
In 2009, he accompanied Bill Clinton to North Korea for negotiations securing the release of two American journalists imprisoned on espionage charges.
President Obama holds a meeting with Podesta and Susan Rice aboard Air Force One, 2015
Podesta opposes the excessive use of classification, and in a 2004 speech at Princeton University condemned what he called the U.S.'s 'excessive government secrecy' and 'bloated secrecy bureaucracy'.

At a 2002 news conference organized by Coalition for Freedom of Information Podesta stated that, 'It is time for the government to declassify records that are more than 25 years old and to provide scientists with data that will assist in determining the real nature of this phenomenon.'
of the University Philosophical Society in March 2006.
Podesta has served on the board of directors of Joule Unlimited since January 2011.
In 2013, Podesta earned $90,000 as a consultant to the West Chester, Pennsylvania-based HJW Foundation.
After the 2016 election, Podesta joined The Washington Post as a columnist.
On September 2, 2022, President Joe Biden appointed Podesta as senior advisor to the president for clean energy innovation and implementation.
He left to succeed John Kerry in the role of U.S. Special Presidential Envoy for Climate in 2024.
The White House Office on Clean Energy Innovation and Implementation was abolished by President Trump by his 'Unleashing American Energy' executive order on January 20th, 2025.
On October 7, 2016, WikiLeaks started to publish thousands of emails reportedly retrieved from Podesta's private Gmail account.

Chicago, Illinois
a think tank in Washington, D.C.
Podesta spent most of his early years in Chicago, where he was born
growing up in the neighborhood of Jefferson Park on the city's Northwest Side
In 1971, he graduated from Knox College in Galesburg, Illinois
a Washington, D.C., 'government relations and public affairs' lobbying firm.
In 2009, he accompanied Bill Clinton to North Korea for negotiations securing the release of two American journalists imprisoned on espionage charges.
Podesta has served on the board of directors of Bedford, Massachusetts–based energy company Joule Unlimited since January 2011.
He has also served on the board of the Portland, Oregon-based Equilibrium Capital.
In 2013, Podesta earned $90,000 as a consultant to the West Chester, Pennsylvania-based HJW Foundation.
He and his wife Mary Podesta, a Washington, D.C., attorney, married in 1978 and have three children.
